children.value: Viewing and comparing across the commit history
What is version control (and why should we care)?

children.label: What is version control (and why should we care)?

children.value: refers generally to systems for managing changes to documents or files. Version control systems let us keep track of what changes were made to a file, when they were made, and by whom. If you’ve ever used “Tracked changes” on a Word document with multiple authors, then you’ve seen a form of version control in action (though NOT one that is well suited to working with computer code!).
The need for version control is particularly acute when
, where small changes to the text can have huge impacts on the results of running the code.
Do you have a directory somewhere on your machine right now with five different versions of a Python script like this?
) like git will replace this mess with a
of edits that you can freely browse through, and will greatly simplify collaborating with other people on writing new code.
That’s the first thing to understand. GitHub is a web-based platform for hosting code and collaborating with other people. On the other hand,
git is a command-line Version Control System (

that you can download and install. It runs on your local computer as well as under the hood on GitHub. You need to understand something about version control with git in order to use many of GitHub’s collaboration features.
. It was originally written by Linus Torvalds specifically for use in development of the Linux kernel. Git is
and comes pre-installed on many Linux and Mac OS systems.
s out there. A few that you might encounter in scientific codebases include
of choice for open-source projects in the Scientific Python ecosystem these days (as well as among software developers more generally).
There is no universally agreed-upon meaning of the name “git”. From the
The name “git” was given by Linus Torvalds when he wrote the very first version. He described the tool as “the stupid content tracker” and the name as (depending on your mood):
random three-letter combination that is pronounceable, and not actually used by any common UNIX command. The fact that it is a mispronunciation of “get” may or may not be relevant.
stupid. contemptible and despicable. simple. Take your pick from the dictionary of slang.
“global information tracker”: you’re in a good mood, and it actually works for you. Angels sing, and a light suddenly fills the room.
“goddamn idiotic truckload of sh*t”: when it breaks

Aside from being free and widely deployed, an important distinguishing feature of git is that it is a distributed Version Control System. Essentially this means that every git directory on every computer is a complete independent repository with complete history.
section, we not only copied the current repository files but also the entire revision history of the repo.
In this section we are going to explore basic git usage
. Nothing that we do here is going to affect other copies of the repositories stored elsewhere.
So don’t worry about breaking anything!
Later, we will explore how to collaborate on code repositories using GitHub. But in keep in mind the basic idea that
all git repos are equal and independent
! You will have separate copies of repos stored on your local machine and in your GitHub organization.
Now that we are oriented, let’s dive into some basic git usage with the

children.label: Inspect a git repository with git status

children.value: First, make sure you followed the steps in the
lesson to make a clone of the
repo on your local computer. Navigate to wherever you saved your copy of the repo.
Now meet your new best friend:
which will always give you information about the current git repo. Try it! You should see something like this:

On branch main
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.

nothing to commit, working tree clean
The first line show you the current
). We’ll cover branching in more detail in the
, but basically each branch is a completely independent version with its own history. When we start making changes to files, we’ll have to pay attention to which branch we’re currently on.
nothing to commit, working tree clean
tells us that we haven’t made any changes to files.
frequently to keep track of things in your repos.
Version control is all about keeping track of changes made to files. So let’s make some changes!
You may have noticed that the file
repository contains a typo. Here we’re going to fix the error and save it locally.
Before we start editing files, the first thing to do is to
where we can safely make any changes we want.
While there’s nothing stopping us from making changes directly to the
branch, it’s often best to avoid this! The reason is that it makes collaboration trickier. See the
Let’s create and checkout a new branch in one line:
Now try your new best friend again:
You should see something like this:

On branch fix-typo
nothing to commit, working tree clean
This tells us that we have switched over to a new branch called
, but there are not (yet) any changes to the files in the repo.
Using your favorite text editor, open the file
. It should now show something like this:

On branch fix-typo
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
	modified:   sample.txt

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
is telling us that the file
Of course we know what changed in that file because we just finished editing it. But here’s a quick and easy way to see the changes:
which should show you something like this:

diff --git a/sample.txt b/sample.txt
index 4bc074c..edc31c0 100644
--- a/sample.txt
+++ b/sample.txt
@@ -4,6 +4,6 @@ We can use it to demonstrate making pull requests or raising issues in a GitHub

 One good way to contribute to a project is to make additions and/or edits to documentation!

-Fxing something as simple as a typo is a great way to get started as a contributor!
+Fixing something as simple as a typo is a great way to get started as a contributor!

 Or, consider adding some more content to this file.
finds the line(s) where our current file differs from what’s in the repo, along with a few lines before and after for context.
The next step is to add our changes to the “official” history of our repo. This is a two-step process (staging and committing).
is the centerpiece of the git workflow. Each commit is a specific set of changes, additions, and/or deletions of files that gets added to the official history of the repository.

Before we make a commit, we must first stage our changes. Think of staging simply as “getting ready to commit”. The two-step process can help avoid accidentally committing something that wasn’t ready.
To stage our changes, we use
and now our new best friend tells us

On branch fix-typo
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
	modified:   sample.txt
Now we see that all-important line
, telling us the contents of our staging area.
If you made a mistake (e.g., staged the wrong file), you can always unstage using
output. Nothing is permanent until we commit!
(And if you accidentally commit the wrong thing? Don’t worry, you can always “go back in time” to previous commits -- see below!)
It’s time to make a commitment. We can now permanently add our edit to the history of our
Every commit should have a “message” that explains briefly what the commit is for. Here we set the commit message with the
flag and chose some descriptive text. Note, it’s critical to have those quotes around
. Otherwise the command shell will misinterpret what you are trying to do.

On branch fix-typo
nothing to commit, working tree clean
And we’re back to a clean state! We have now added a new permanent change to the history of our repo (or more specifically, to this
Each commit is essentially a snapshot in time of the state of the repo. So how can we look back on that history, or revert back to a previous version of a file?

children.label: Viewing the commit history with git log

children.value: A simple way to see this history of the current branch is this:

commit 7dca0292467e4bbd73643556f83fd1c52b5c113c (HEAD -> fix-typo)
Author: Brian Rose <brose@albany.edu>
Date:   Mon Jan 17 11:31:49 2022 -0500

    Fix the typo

commit 35fcbd991f911e170df550db58f74a082ba18b50 (origin/main, origin/HEAD, main)
Author: Kevin Tyle <ktyle@albany.edu>
Date:   Thu Jan 13 11:29:40 2022 -0500

    Close docstring quote on sample.py

commit e56ea58071f150ec00904a50341a672456cbcb8f
Author: Kevin Tyle <ktyle@albany.edu>
Date:   Tue Jan 11 14:15:31 2022 -0500

    Create sample.md

commit f98d05e312d19a84b74c45402a2904ab94d86e45
Author: Kevin Tyle <ktyle@albany.edu>
Date:   Tue Jan 11 13:58:09 2022 -0500

    Create sample.py

which shows the last few commits on this branch, including the commit number, author, timestamp, and commit message. You can page down to see the rest of the history
or just press
Every commit has a unique hexadecimal checksum code like
. Your history will look a little different from the above!
Let’s say you want to retrieve the file
from the previous commit. Two possible reasons why:
You just want to take a quick look at something in the previous commit, but then go back to the current version. That’s what we’ll do here.
Maybe you don’t like the most recent commit and want to do some new edits
-- in effect, undoing the most recent commit and going back in time. The simplest way to do this is to
starting from the previous commit. We’ll cover branches more fully in the next lesson.
To retrieve the previous commit, just use
and the unique number code which you can just copy and paste from the
You may see output that looks like this:

Note: switching to '35fcbd991f911e170df550db58f74a082ba18b50'.

You are in 'detached HEAD' state. You can look around, make experimental
changes and commit them, and you can discard any commits you make in this
state without impacting any branches by switching back to a branch.

If you want to create a new branch to retain commits you create, you may
do so (now or later) by using -c with the switch command. Example:

  git switch -c <new-branch-name>

Or undo this operation with:

  git switch -

Turn off this advice by setting config variable advice.detachedHead to false

HEAD is now at 35fcbd9 Close docstring quote on sample.py
(the details may vary depending on what version of git you are running).
, git is telling us that we are NOT on the most recent commit in this branch.
in your editor, you will see that the typo
As the git message above is reminding us, it’s possible to create an entirely new branch with changes that we make from this point in the history using
. But for now, let’s just go back to the most recent commit on our
We already saw one use of the
command to look at changes in a repo. By default
will compare the currently saved files against the most recent commit.
to compare across commits within a branch, or between two different branches. Here are some examples.
To compare across any commits in our history, we again use the unique commit checksum that we listed with

Commands we used in this tutorial

children.label: Commands we used in this tutorial

children.value: : see what branch we’re on and what state our repo is in.
flag to create a new branch and check it out)

git checkout -b new-branch-name
    git checkout <unique-code-of-commit>
    git checkout branch-name
: compare files between current version and last commit (default), between two commits, or between two branches.

git diff commit-one commit-two
    git diff branch-one..branch-two
: stage a file for a commit.
: create a new commit with the staged files.
: see the commit history of our branch.
Some other git commands you’ll want to know

children.label: Some other git commands you’ll want to know

children.value: We’ll cover many of these in subsequent sections.
: list all the branch in the repo
(remove file) commands. These will automatically stage the changes in your current branch.
: merge changes from one branch into another.
: export or input changes between your local branch and a remote repository (e.g. hosted on GitHub).
: create a brand-new repo in the current directory
Version control is an important tool for working with code files (or anything that is saved as plain text).
git is the most common version control software in use today.
is your new best friend because it gives you a quick view into what’s going on in a git repository.
Every branch of a git repository has a history which is a series of numbered and labelled commits.
You can view this history with
Making a new commit is a two-step process with
Commits are non-destructive, meaning you can always go back in time to previous commits.
Next we’ll explore the concept of branching in git repositories in more detail, including how to merge changes made on one branch into another branch.
The Software Carpentries beginner lessons on git
